comment._content: OMG he's only a boy. So sad. Hero.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69662531@N05] Thank you for all your great work on this photo and many others in this set, we really appreciate it. This is exactly what we hoped people might do, so we are very grateful. We are going to be announcing a major project seeking everyone's help to uncover the life stories of those who served in the First World War.Watch out for announcements on: Our website www.1914.org Our Facebook page Our Twitter account Thank you again.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: Thanks to everyone for your comments. If you have a spare minute, please light a light to help us remember those who died in the First World War, at www.1914.org/wall/

comment.author: 72016174@N08
comment._content:
He was my 2nd Cousin,  1x removed

His father was a Sgt Major who reenlisted when 39 in 1915
Clarence G Williams, Army Service Corps, 
Border Regiment Regimental Number: T4/123287, 39451

His father was subsequently Registrar for Newport.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
I strongly suspect that Gunner John Phelps Williams served in 2nd/"B" (2nd City of London Horse Artillery Battery) Honourable Artillery Company, part of the Territorial RHA, originally formed to support the Mounted (Yeomanry) Divisions of the Territorial Force. 

In April 1917 2nd/"B" Battery HAC, equipped with 18-pounders, was in 126th Army Artillery Brigade, supporting 108th Brigade of 36th (Ulster) Division (consisting 9th, 11th, 12th and 13th Battalions of the Royal Irish Rifles).  36th (Ulster) Division was at this time preparing for the assault on 7th June 1917 to capture the Messines-Wytschaete Ridge.//
